title: Hands-on With Apache Cassandra ACID Transactions
description:
After a long wait in alpha status, the long-awaited ACID transaction functionality is starting to make its way into users' hands. In this workshop, I will show you how to set up your own test instance of Apache Cassandra and run some examples. Hands on! As this new functionality becomes a reality, we must get user feedback. Hereâ€™s your opportunity to try it, and tell us what you think!

Some of the things you should expect:

Install and run ACID enabled Cassandra locally or in the cloud
Syntax breakdown and how to make a transactional query
Amazing new use cases to try
How to provide feedback to help improve the feature

Additional Resources:
- DataStax Developer Hub: https://datastax.com/devs
- DataStax Blog: https://www.datastax.com/blog/technical-how-tos
- Langflow: https://langflow.datastax.com
- Astra DB: https://astra.datastax.com
____________________

Stay in touch:
- Join our Discord Community: https://discord.gg/datastax
- Follow us on X: https://x.com/DataStaxDevs

is happening at uh at Apple this is just full disclosure the Apple the the cord team is is almost exclusively at Apple of course they are very interested in this for lots of reasons and I'm sure you can understand why um I know they're working on the performance aspects they the last time I talked to some of the some of the people working on it they said the performance was uh was okay and what that means is that it works and um it it holds up to some load but when when I hear that I'm like okay there we're we're getting ready to do a real solid performance test and a lot of it is just because the features go in and you you run into you have like inconsistencies and how it works and then it can drive a little bit of a performance problem um meaning like oh we have a race condition or something like that that needs to be dealt with um I guarantee you performance will be top of mine on everyone's list so the goal I think is that it will shouldn't be any less performant than using lightweight transactions of course when you're doing a full asset transaction it will vary greatly on how many uh how many different uh select statements or how many different mutations you have inside of the asset transaction um we're not going to guarantee the same like if you're doing one mutation or a thousand mutations it's exactly the same that's never that's never going to be a guarantee um and as of transactions um I'll just kind of blend this into what attia was asking is um we want so this is the goal for a cord is that and this is why we didn't use spanner or raft or any of those other Calvin the reason we didn't go down the path of using an existing consensus protocol is because they didn't match up the way that Cassandra worked and so if you look at our three really important tenants with Cassandra is the linear scaling the multi-data center support just natively and the resilience like how it handles failure you can crush a container cluster and still have it be online so those three things if if those are our our tenants that we can't violate then looking at other like spanner spanner does not allow for that um Calvin does not allow for that and so you know we would have to violate the way conand works so a long way to answer your question um adou you you asked the best one which is yes right out of the box multi Data Center and low latency across multiple data centers um and that's that's just that's the part of what has to happen and um and it will be dialable and just like with Quorum you can do local Quorum you can do full Quorum you can do each Quorum there's a lot of things we want to put a lot of control in your hands and give you the choices instead of just making choices there are some things that you know if you're doing an assd transaction it's going to be assd you can't dial that back um but multi active active is definitely a big part of it but I'm glad that's a good question because it gets down to like why we're doing this why we're spending the time um yeah so the data so this is what's interesting about why asset transactions on cander work the way they do is um in a lot of times when you when you work in a distributed system and you're trying to do an ass transaction it's about how much data are you locking and so if you have a thousand node cluster do you want to lock the entire cluster to have an asset transaction well no and we know and this is the advantage we have to Sandra is we know exactly where all the data is based on token ranges so every node has a certain range of data we know exactly who they are there's another feature that's coming with a chord that I haven't talked a lot about and it's called transactional metadata and this is this is the big change that's coming with asset transactions that that you probably haven't even heard about which is we're changing the way that Cassandra works from an operation standpoint now you've heard about gossip gossip is a way that whenever you make a change it permeates throughout the cholester propagates and says hey I made a change or here's a state change or anything and it's non-deterministic it just kind of floats through the cluster and it could take you know a few seconds a few minutes sometimes it doesn't do take it takes much longer that's not good if you're going to make a schema change or something like that so transactional cluster metadata takes that assd transaction assd transaction um to the metadata in the cluster itself so for instance if you add a new node to the system you know the the guidance right now if you're working on a cassander cluster is if you need to add say 10 nodes to your cluster to scale it then you have to give like three or four minutes before between each one to let gossip settle up to let the ranges settle and now you can just say give me 10 more nodes it's a transaction and you can instantly add 10 notes um that is going to be a game changer for sure U but or you want to take it back you know 20 noes you want to scale back okay bam done well when you look at the data synchronization and large clustered asset transactions we will know exactly where it is so again limiting how many of those nodes participate in the asset transaction so if I only have three replicas only three noes we able will have to participate in that transaction and that's where the performance is that's where the the um resilience comes in and then doing in the way that we do across data center with only one mutation across to a coordinator keeps that low as well so everything
